historicalName: Calle del Scarlatto, Sestiere di Castello
historicalDescription: This street was located in the Castello sestiere, one of the six districts of Venice. In the 15th century, Castello was known for its naval shipyards, the Arsenale, and numerous churches.

canalPoints.historicalDescription: Named after the scarlet cloth dyers who operated workshops in this area of Castello during the Renaissance. The name 'Scarlatto' (Scarlet) in Calle del Scarlatto directly references this trade, which was highly regulated by the Venetian Republic due to the valuable dyes used in creating the vibrant red cloths favored by nobility.

This dock would be named after the nearby Church of San Martino in Castello, one of the historic parish churches in this sestiere. During the Renaissance, many Venetian docks were named after the closest religious landmarks, which served as important navigation and community reference points. San Martino was particularly important to the working-class residents of Castello.

Located in Castello near the great Venetian Arsenal, this dock would serve the specialized workers (Arsenalotti) who built and maintained Venice's renowned fleet. The Arsenalotti held special privileges in Venetian society and many lived in this eastern part of the city to be close to their workplace. This landing would have been used for transporting materials and workers to the nearby shipyards.

connection.historicalDescription: Named after the 'tintori' (dyers) who specialized in scarlet fabric in this area of Castello. The name 'Calle del Scarlatto' itself indicates this was a location where scarlet dyeing took place, an important and prestigious craft in Renaissance Venice that produced the vibrant red textiles favored by Venetian nobility.

Located near the Venetian Arsenal, this bridge would have been frequently crossed by the 'arsenalotti' (arsenal workers) who were highly respected craftsmen in Renaissance Venice. The Castello district housed the Arsenal, the largest pre-industrial production complex in Europe, and many bridges in this area connected the arsenal workers' residences to their workplace.

buildingPoints.streetDescription: Named after the scarlet dye workshops once located in this area of Castello. Scarlet cloth was a prestigious export of Venice, and the tintori (dyers) who specialized in creating this vibrant red color formed an important guild. This street would have housed several of these specialized artisans.

A waterside street where boats would deliver raw wool to be dyed scarlet. The location near a canal would be practical for the transportation of materials and finished products. The name reflects the connection between the wool trade and the scarlet dyeing industry prevalent in this part of Castello.

Named after the noble Grimani family who owned property in this area of Castello. The Grimani were a powerful nobili family who contributed several Doges to Venice and were known patrons of the arts. Their presence in this district would have been marked by family palaces or properties.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Filled Canal of the Arsenal Workers
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A former canal that was filled in and converted to a street, located near the Venetian Arsenal. The Arsenalotti were the specialized workers of the Arsenal shipyard, who held special privileges and formed a distinct social class in Venice. This area of Castello was home to many Arsenal workers due to its proximity to the shipyards.

buildingPoints.streetNameEnglish: Covered Passageway of the Levantine Merchants
buildingPoints.streetDescription: A covered passage named after the Levantine (Eastern Mediterranean) merchants who traded in this area. Castello's proximity to the eastern edge of Venice made it a natural location for merchants trading with the East. These merchants would have dealt in luxury goods including the dyes needed for scarlet cloth production.

A paved street named after a religious confraternity or scuola that was active in this part of Castello. These lay brotherhoods were important social institutions in Renaissance Venice, providing mutual aid and religious services. The name suggests this was one of the early paved streets in the area, possibly funded by the brotherhood.

Named after the Byzantine influence on Venetian scarlet dyeing techniques. Venice's connections with Byzantium brought technical knowledge of dyeing methods, and this street near Calle del Scarlatto would commemorate this historical connection. The Byzantine red was particularly prized for its durability and brilliance.

A commercial street where silk workers had their shops. Silk was often dyed scarlet for luxury garments, creating a natural proximity between silk workers and scarlet dyers in this area of Castello. The term 'Ruga' typically indicates a street with shops and commercial activities.

A small square named after cochineal, an insect-derived dye imported from the New World that revolutionized scarlet production in the 16th century. This gathering place would have been a spot where dyers and merchants might have met to discuss or trade this valuable dyestuff near the scarlet workshops.

A courtyard where the large vats (tinelli) used for dyeing fabrics would have been located. This enclosed space would have contained the workshops where the actual dyeing process took place, kept separate from residential areas due to the strong smells and potential for contamination from the dyes.

Named after a shrine or church feature depicting the Madonna dressed in scarlet robes, likely funded by the prosperous dyers' guild. Religious dedications were common in street names, and this would reflect the devotion of the local craftsmen who specialized in producing the valuable scarlet dye.

A small side street or branch where various purple dyes, related to but distinct from scarlet, were produced or sold. The name reflects the variety of red-purple dyes that were important in Venetian textile production, with this particular branch specializing in purples rather than true scarlets.
